query: I'm 16 and help care for my mother who has MS in gloucestershire. This is affecting my schoolwork. Is there any support for young carers?

years . 
3.6.3 Young Carers  
2011 census data indicates there are over 1600 children and young people aged 17 
and younger providing unpaid care in Gloucestershire. The caring role undertaken 
varies from a child helping pa rents to bathe a disabled brother or sister to being the 
sole support for a lone parent with a severe mental health or physical condition. 
Evidence suggests that young carers are more likely to have significantly lower 
levels of educational attainment than  their peers and are more likely than the 
national average to be ‘not in education, employment or training’ (NEET) between 
the ages of 16 and 1924. 
 
3.6.4 Carers with  Impairment  
Many carers report that caring results in a negative and often lasting impact o n their 
physical and mental health, but as with the rest of the population, many people with 
existing impairments or long -term conditions also take on caring responsibilities.

. Where to find support The Gloucestershire Carers Hub is commissioned by us to support you in your caring role. As well as a range of resources, the Hub offers a safe space to talk about your caring role, and to share any worries or concerns with one of their team. You can contact them by calling 0300 111 9000, or by email at: carers@peopleplus.co.uk. The Care and Advice Line provides a free, confidential, one-to-one service dealing with all aspects of care including support for unpaid carers. Call 01452 222 200 to speak to a member of their team. Gloucestershire Young Carers provide information and support for children and young people who are carrying out significant caring tasks and taking on responsibility that would ordinarily be done by an adult. You can also find further resources in the Carers section of our website

Our current position...
We currently work in line with the ‘Special educational needs and disability (SEND) code of practice: 
0 to 25 years’ guidance which means that children, young people and parents are provided with the 
information, advice and support necessary when planning for their transition to adult life, the future 
and how to prepare for it, including their health, where they will live, their relationships, control of 
their finances, how they will participate in the community and achieve greater independence.
The Care Advice Line service in Gloucestershire provides free information and advice to help people 
plan to pay for their care. Advice can be provided to young people who are transitioning to adult 
services.

answer:
Yes, there is support available for young carers like you in Gloucestershire. **Gloucestershire Young Carers** provides information and support specifically for young people who are carrying out significant caring tasks.

- **Contact Information**: You can reach out to Gloucestershire Young Carers for support by calling **01452 733060** or emailing **mail@glosyoungcarers.org.uk**. They offer resources and a safe space to discuss your caring role and any concerns you might have.

- **Additional Support**: The **Gloucestershire Carers Hub** is another resource that offers support for carers. They can be contacted at **0300 111 9000** or via email at **carers@peopleplus.co.uk**.

- **Impact on Education**: It's noted that young carers often face challenges with educational attainment. Therefore, reaching out to these organizations can help you access support that might alleviate some of the pressures affecting your schoolwork.

For more detailed information and resources, you can visit the Gloucestershire Carers Support webpage at [Gloucestershire Carers Support](https://www.gloucestershire.gov.uk/health-and-social-care/carers/gloucestershire-carers-support-and-more/).
